title: Are the Albanians the oldest Europeans? - Quora

response.answer_text: Question: Are Albanians the oldest Europeans? Short answer: Not exactly. Long answer: Basque and Caucasian people are the oldest in Europe, because they are the only pre-Indo-Europeans in the continent, however, Albanians are the oldest or one of the oldest in the Balkans. But… are Albanians the oldest I.E. in Europe? Unfortunately no, Albanian is a semi-Romanized language, ~1/3 of our vocabulary derives from Latin, other influences arrives also from Slavic, Germanic, Hellenic and Turkic languages, maybe Celtic and Indo-Iranic influenced Albanian too, so, our language lost many of its original characteristics, don't forget that we mixed with the pre-Indo-European populations of the Balkans (Pelasgians), so we are not the oldest I.E. in Europe, but we are the oldest in the Balkans. The ancient Thracians, Illyrians and Dacians form a possible I.E. branch called “Thraco-Illyrian”, and arrived in the Balkans more than 3000 years ago, maybe 5000, however, one of those populations mixed with ancient Pelasgians and thanks to them we have the ancestors of modern Albanians.  Baltic languages (especially Lithuanian) are more closer to proto-I.E., they were conquered many “few” times than Albanians, so, their language has less foreign loanwords, but despite that, they absorbed a pre-I.E. population as well, a substrate was found, and it is pretty similar to the same substrate found in Saami and Balto-Finnic languages, is possible that the same pre-Indo-European population inhabited both Fenno-Scandia and the Baltic? We don't know! However, Balto-Slavic languages and Albanian share many things in common, Germanic languages shares many features as well, more than other I.E. languages, so, we and the Baltics are the oldest I.E. in Europe, but Baltics are a bit older than us, and as I said before, Caucasian languages and Basque still living in their respective territories before us I.E. started to spread among Eurasia, but we still one of the oldest in the Balkans!

Genetically, this question doesn’t make a lot of sense, since Europeans are pretty much very well intermixed, even moreso in the case of Mediterranean populations (the Romans did a rather thorough and good job at that). So I guess this is more a question from a linguistic/cultural angle. Albanians are Indo-European. The ancestors of the Albanians reached Europe most likely at some time around 3000~6000 years ago; just like ancient Greeks, what would become Germanic, Balto-Slavic, Celtic and Italic tribes and other now extinct Indo-European branches (like Hittites) settled other areas of Europe. But they weren’t the first settlers, there were already non-Indo-Erupean peoples in Europe (Etruscans, Iberians, Aquitanians, Minoans, Raetics, Nuraghics, Tartesians…). Only one European language and culture from before the arrival of Indo-Europeans has survived to this day: Basque. So, if there’s such a thing as “oldest European people”, that would definitely be the Basques.

How do you mean? Like, that they got there before the others from Asia? Basques have almost certainly been in Europe longer than any Indo-European culture, including Albanians. Albanians did clearly get to southeast Europe before the Slavs and Germans did, but there is nothing to suggest (that I’ve ever read) that they got there before the Greeks or Celts. It’s largely uncertain because it is unclear who they were in the ancient world. The first clear reference to modern Albanians is by Byzantine historians just 1000 years ago. They may be descendants of Thracians or Illyrians or a different group entirely. There just isn’t the evidence to say, even though that doesn’t stop plenty of armchair historians from pretending they know the answer.

This question really doesn't make a lot of sense. How could you tell from an entire nation of ethically diverse people (mixing from Turks, Greeks, Serbs, Romans) which are “older Europeans”? That's like asking if Kenyans are the oldest Africans, when there have been many different people during different periods. Albanians, Bosnians and Croats all have percentages ofIllyrian ancestry depending on each person. So yes they belong to one of the oldest Indo-European ethnic groups but they're not solely the oldest.
